zone.line: When I had arrived at the nearest
town I took post horses and ^followed folled the
road my father had taken. At every
inn where we changed horses ^we I heard
heard of him, and I was possessed
by aller alternate hope and fear.
A length I foumd found that he
had altered his route; at first he
had followed the London road; but
now he changed it, and upon enqui
ry I found that the one which he
now pursued led towards the sea. My
dream recurred to my thoughts; I was
not usually superstitious but in
wretchedness every one is so. The sea
was fifty miles off, yet it was towards
it that he fled. The idea was terrible
to my half crazed imagination, and
almost overturned the little l self
possession that still remained to me.
I journied all day; every moment my
misery encreased and the fever of my
